pullRequest.body:
This is WIP.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>Decrease in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (3.09, 0.02)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|4952|-25|porting notes|
|201|-1|disabled simpNF lints|
|1487|-12|erw|

Current commit [84c70c13bf](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/84c70c13bf8502e5e8158ad269bd55766663a5e4)
Reference commit [fb9a612d26](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/fb9a612d26b507a6a183124d6b87e3996c30e33c)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I am happy to mark this as ready for review if we address the notes I left. (We might also want to have some sort of systematic check that all our work happened correctly in parallel for all four `RingCat`s.)

I am happy to mark this as ready for review if we address the notes I left. (We might also want to have some sort of systematic check that all our work happened correctly in parallel for all four `RingCat`s.)

This is horrible. All this back and forth between `Hom.hom` and the `DFunLike.coe` coming from `ConcreteCategory.instFunLike` is needed to prevent the original `rw` from becoming an `erw`.

I think it would help if we replace `ConcreteCategory.instFunLike` by a `CoeFun`, but this of course also has some fallout, so I did not do a full test.

The remaining goal after `simp` is `⊢ (R.val ⋙ forget RingCat).map (g ≫ f.unop).op r = (R.val.map g.op).hom ((R.val.map f).hom r)`, should we have a (non-`@[simp]`) lemma for `(forget RingCat).map f = f.hom`?
We have this lemma already :)
Would this `haveI` be worth making this a proper instance? (Also, I don't think we need the inline `haveI` here, a `have` is fine.)
Made it a standalone instance, although I don't think it really matters much.
Should at least be squeezed.
I think you already fixed this one.
This seems to be a change to `ext`, now applying `MvPolynomial`'s ext lemmas. Don't know what we want to do about this, I think this is fine and maybe even better than before.
I think it is better in the sense that this is how `ext` should behave. To restore the old proof `ext : 1; apply RingHom.ext` would work, but I think it is good as is.

I tried extracting this as a lemma:
```lean

@[simp]
lemma CommRingCat.iso_inv_hom_apply {R S : CommRingCat.{u}} (e : R ≅ S) (x) :
    e.inv.hom (e.hom.hom x) = x :=
  e.hom_inv_id_apply x

@[simp]
lemma CommRingCat.iso_hom_inv_apply {R S : CommRingCat.{u}} (e : R ≅ S) (x) :
    e.hom.hom (e.inv.hom x) = x :=
  e.inv_hom_id_apply x
```

but `simp only [CommRingCat.iso_hom_inv_apply]` makes no progress here (`rw` does make progress...)

If we can correct it, I think we should have that lemma for all the `RingCat`s.

We already have these as `<...Cat>.inv_hom_apply` and `<...Cat>.hom_inv_apply`, but indeed they don't trigger here.
`simp` does apply with this brutal `no_index`ing:
```
@[simp]
lemma my_hom_inv_apply {R S : CommRingCat} (e : R ≅ S) (s : S) :
    @DFunLike.coe no_index _ _ _ _ e.hom.hom
      (@DFunLike.coe no_index _ no_index _ _ _ e.inv.hom s) = s := by
  rw [← CommRingCat.comp_apply]
  simp

#discr_tree_key my_hom_inv_apply
-- @Eq _.1 (@DFunLike.coe _ _.1 _ _ _.1.1 (@DFunLike.coe _ _ _ _ _.2.1 _)) _
```
I don't really understand this `discr_tree_key` output I think. What do these `.1` and `.2.1`s refer to? To me this looks very bad, as it does not seem to mention `CommRingCat` anywhere. For comparison, these are the keys without `no_index`:
```
-- @Eq _.1 (@DFunLike.coe (RingHom _.1 _.1 _ _) _.1 _ _ _.1.1 (@DFunLike.coe (RingHom _.1 _.1 _ _) _.1 _ _ _.2.1 _)) _
```

Basically all of these `germ` lemmas assume a concrete category and `forget` which doesn't unify with `CommRingCat.carrier` / `CommRingCat.Hom.hom`.

My proposal is to keep this for now and hope that we can restate those results as something along the lines of the `BundledHomCategory`.
Still not sure what's going on here (or below).

Okay I think I get what's going on here: The issue lies in the implicit `R` argument of `Q` caused by def-eq abuse of the (not reducible) equality:
```
(Γ(↑(Y.basicOpen r), ⊤) : Type u) = (Γ(Y, (Y.basicOpen r).ι ''ᵁ ⊤) : Type u)
```
More generally this holds for any open `U` in place of `Y.basicOpen r`. This def-eq abuse is introduced by the lemma `AlgebraicGeometry.morphismRestrict_appTop`. Indeed, replacing the invocation of `morphismRestrict_appTop` by
```
theorem morphismRestrict_appTop' {X Y : Scheme.{u}} (f : X ⟶ Y) (U : Y.Opens) :
    (f ∣_ U).appTop = eqToHom rfl ≫ f.app (U.ι ''ᵁ ⊤) ≫
        X.presheaf.map (eqToHom (image_morphismRestrict_preimage f U ⊤)).op :=
  morphismRestrict_app ..
```
fixes it. So again a lemma that is not reducibly type correct, not related to this refactor. What I still don't understand is why it works on master.

- How hard is it to write a linter flagging not-reducibly type correct lemmas?
- Maybe a `reelab` tactic could be helpful, that just re-elaborates the type of the goal (or possibly a hypothesis) with some `reelab at foo` syntax? Possibly even a `rw_reelab` could automatically run `reelab` after `rw`.

This should probably be upstreamed somewhere: `set_option linter.minImports` suggests it should go to the join of ` Mathlib.Topology.Sheaves.Presheaf` and `Mathlib.Algebra.Category.Ring.Basic`, which I am not familiar enough with this library to find easily.

(Also there are a couple instances in other files where I had to do `restrictOpen (C := CommRingCat)`, I ended up adding it here because this file needed the hint *a lot*.)

(Good `ImportGraph` feature idea?)
Is that combination worth it or are we now going to have to redefine every concrete categorical result for `RingCat`s?

I still believe that we should get rid of the generic `FunLike` instance on `ConcreteCategory` and instead either state everything that currently needs it for `BundledHomCategory` or have `ConcreteCategory` carry an explicit `CoeFun`, so that the generic `hom` and the `<...>Cat.Hom.hom` coincide reducibly.

Ah sorry, I did not pay attention well enough here: The lemma that is applied here is `RingHom.RespectsIso.cancel_left_isIso` which is only relevant for `CommRingCat` anyway. So I think this is independent of the concrete category issue. Since `hom_comp` is `@[simp]`, I think we don't need a second version here.
This instance suggests we don't always see correctly through structure eta when looking for instances... Is that something that we can control?

It needs again 3 `no_index` to fix it:
```
instance isLocalHom_stalkClosedPointTo :
    @IsLocalHom no_index _ no_index _ no_index _ _ _ _ (stalkClosedPointTo f).hom :=
  inferInstanceAs <| IsLocalHom (f.stalkMap (closedPoint R) ≫ (stalkClosedPointIso R).hom).hom
```
When inspecting the discr tree keys for both instances, ignoring the additional `CommRingCat.mk`s, the noticeable difference is: `(closedPoint _.1 _ _)` in the un-primed version vs `(closedPoint _ _ _)` in the primed version. Again I don't really understand what this `_.1` means.

I think we should see it as separating the "concrete category is one with a forgetful functor to `Type`" and "concrete category is one where the morphisms are `FunLike`s". The latter can imply the former, but crucially we'd need the actual `FunLike` instances to be passed in, not created by `ConcreteCategory`.
I agree, but I am still suspicious of `FunLike` and would prefer a `CoeFun` (manually passed in as you say), since this seems to create less issues with implicit type mismatches.
The two sides of the goal look identical, so I think this `rw` is okay.
Do you mean the `rfl`?
The `erw` + `show` should be solvable by using a lemma specialized to `CommRingCat.Hom.hom`, but I don't know if that is worth the duplication.
This one is solvable by two explicit `rw`s in the right directions. I think that's better, do you agree?

pullRequest.title: refactor(Algebra/Category/Ring): make morphisms a structure

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
